Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: The acquaintance's car has broken down on a quiet road, and they are calling for assistance.
Situation2: They conduct an in-depth consultation with a patient taking multiple high-risk medications to prevent dangerous interactions.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to begin a crucial medication review with Mrs. Lee, a patient who’d recently started a complicated regimen of blood thinners and antiarrhythmics. I glanced at the screen—Tom, an old friend from college, was calling. I hesitated, but answered, keeping my voice low. Tom’s car had broken down on a deserted stretch of road, and he sounded anxious. “Can you come get me? I don’t know who else to call,” he pleaded. My mind raced. As a friend, I wanted to drop everything and help him, to be the support he needed. But as a pharmacist, I was about to counsel Mrs. Lee, whose safety depended on my undivided attention. The pharmacy was short-staffed; no one else could step in. I could hear Mrs. Lee’s footsteps approaching the consultation room. My heart pounded as I weighed Tom’s urgent need against my professional responsibility. Both roles demanded my presence, but I couldn’t be in two places at once.
